title: 109_hr3629
content: The Act titled "Taking Care of Small Business Tax Simplification Act of 2005" allows for Subchapter S election to be made on tax returns filed before the due date with extensions. The Act "Taking Care of Small Business Tax Simplification Act of 2005" allows small business corporations to make a Subchapter S election on their tax return before the due date with extensions. If a small business corporation fails to meet the requirements of subsection (b) of section 1361 before making a Subchapter S election, or if any stockholders do not consent to the election, the election will be treated as made for the following taxable year. If the election is made after the due date, it will also be treated as made for the following taxable year. If an election under subsection (a) is made after the due date for the return, it will be treated as made for the following taxable year. The Secretary may treat a late election as timely if there was reasonable cause for the delay. The revocation of an election under section 1362(d)(1)(C) of the Code is effective on the 1st day of the taxable year unless specified otherwise. The revocation of an election under section 1362(d)(1)(C) of the Code is effective on the 1st day of the taxable year, and the amendments made by this section apply to elections for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3 provides relief from penalties for timely tax deposits made incorrectly. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide relief from penalties for timely tax deposits made incorrectly. The Secretary may abate penalties if the deposit was made on time but not in the prescribed manner, due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. The penalty percentage shall not exceed 2 percent if conditions are met. The amendment to section 6656(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code includes adding subsection (e) in addition to subparagraph (B). The effective date for these amendments applies to deposits required after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. UNINCORPORATED BUSINESSES OPERATED BY HUSBAND AND WIFE AS CO-OWNERS. Section 761 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new subsection (f) regarding Qualified Joint Ventures conducted by a husband and wife filing a joint return. This joint venture is not treated as a partnership, and income, gain, loss, deduction, and credit are divided between the spouses according to their interests. Each spouse accounts for their share of these items individually. The amendment allows for a qualified joint venture involving a husband and wife to be treated as a sole proprietorship for tax purposes. Both spouses must materially participate in the business and elect to apply this provision. The amendment allows for each spouse's share of income or loss from a qualified joint venture to be considered in determining net earnings from self-employment. The amendment allows each spouse's share of income or loss from a qualified joint venture to be considered in determining net earnings from self-employment, effective for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act.
